fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.env

Class EnvironmentBuilderDelegate<P>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractParent<P>
      • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.env.EnvironmentBuilderDelegate<P>
  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of the parent builder (when calling AbstractParent.and() method)
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<PropertyResolver>, EnvironmentBuilder<P>, Parent<P>

    public class EnvironmentBuilderDelegate<P>
extends AbstractParent<P>
implements EnvironmentBuilder<P>
    Implementation that just delegates all operations to another builder.

    This is useful when a EnvironmentBuilder is used for a particular parent and it must be inherited. As the parent types are not the same, you can't directly use the same reference. So this implementation wraps the original reference but as it is a new instance, it can have a different parent builder.

    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Constructor Detail

      • EnvironmentBuilderDelegate

        public EnvironmentBuilderDelegate(P parent,
                                  EnvironmentBuilder<?> delegate)
        Wraps the delegate builder. The delegated builder parent is not used. This instance uses the provided parent instead for chaining.
        Parameters:
        parent - the new parent used for chaining
        delegate - the instance that will really be updated

    • Method Detail

      • properties

        public EnvironmentBuilder<P> properties(String path)
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Load a property file using its path. The properties are mixed with other registered properties taking into account the priority. The path may contain a lookup prefix:
        • classpath:conf/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" in the classpath
        • file:/home/foo/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" from the file system
        • conf/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" in the classpath

        The priority of the registered properties depends on if the file is loaded from the classpath or from the filesystem. The priority is used to order all registered properties. Registered properties with higher priorities are used first. It means that when requesting for a property value the highest priority is requested first to get the value if it exists. If it doesn't exist, the second is requested and so on. If several properties are registered with the same priority, then the registration order is used.

        The default priorities are:

        • using system properties = 100000
        • load properties from file from the filesystem = 90000
        • using custom Properties object = 80000
        • using custom properties through EnvironmentBuilder.properties() fluent API = 80000
        • load properties from file in the classpath (inside the application) = 70000
        Specified by:
        properties in interface EnvironmentBuilder<P>
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the property file
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

        public EnvironmentBuilder<P> properties(String path,
                                        int priority)
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Load a property file using its path. The properties are mixed with other registered properties taking into account the priority. The path may contain a lookup prefix:
        • classpath:conf/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" in the classpath
        • file:/home/foo/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" from the file system
        • conf/myprops.properties: loads a file named "myprops.properties" in the classpath

        Indicates the priority of the registered properties. The priority is used to order all registered properties. Registered properties with higher priorities are used first. It means that when requesting for a property value the highest priority is requested first to get the value if it exists. If it doesn't exist, the second is requested and so on. If several properties are registered with the same priority, then the registration order is used.

      • converter

        public ConverterBuilder<EnvironmentBuilder<P>> converter()
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Configure how conversions are applied on properties.

        Properties are like a map with a string key and often a string value. In an application, you need to work with real objects (not always strings). The converter will be used to transform a string value that comes from properties into a real object.

        Using the ConverterBuilder is useful to register custom converters.

        Specified by:
        converter in interface EnvironmentBuilder<P>
        Returns:
        the converter builder

      • resolver

        public EnvironmentBuilderDelegate<P> resolver(PropertyResolver resolver)
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Defined a custom PropertyResolver instead of the default one.

        Using a custom PropertyResolver may be useful when default implementation doesn't fit your needs. For example, when using Spring, Ogham will automatically register a property resolver that uses Spring Environment concept.

        Specified by:
        resolver in interface EnvironmentBuilder<P>
        Parameters:
        resolver - the custom resolver
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

        public PropertiesBuilder<EnvironmentBuilder<P>> properties()
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Provide custom properties using fluent API. The properties are mixed with other registered properties taking into account the priority.

        The priority of the registered properties is 80000. The priority is used to order all registered properties. Registered properties with higher priorities are used first. It means that when requesting for a property value the highest priority is requested first to get the value if it exists. If it doesn't exist, the second is requested and so on. If several properties are registered with the same priority, then the registration order is used.

        • using system properties = 100000

        • using custom Properties object = 80000
        • using custom properties through EnvironmentBuilder.properties() fluent API = 80000
        • load properties from file in the classpath (inside the application) = 70000
        Specified by:
        properties in interface EnvironmentBuilder<P>
        Returns:
        the builder to configure properties

      • override

        public EnvironmentBuilder<P> override()
        Description copied from interface: EnvironmentBuilder
        Overrides any previously defined properties. For example: 
         
 .properties("foo.properties")
 .properties(myProperties)
 .systemProperties()
 .override()
 .properties()
   .set("foo", "bar")
        The three first lines won't be taken into account. Only the properties defined after are used.
        Specified by:
        override in interface EnvironmentBuilder<P>
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
